data.title: Not autoscrolling on undo when selection does not change
data.body:
When I undo or redo something, could atom please scroll to the place where the undo/redo actions are having an effect?

I don't know if this is an intermittent or constant issue... if it's intermittent, one way to reproduce is to refresh your editor (ctrl+option+cmd+L) then try to undo a few things and it keeps me - no, _forces me_ - to the top of the file.

data.title: Clicking `Soft Wrap` from the settings view doesn't toggle soft wrap in existing editors.
data.body:
![atom](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/596/2937210/4066ec7a-d88e-11e3-989c-064f375de4ce.gif)

If you click `Soft Wrap` from the settings view it doesn't affect existing editor windows. `window:reload` also won't toggle soft wrap. You have to close and then reopen the file. I assume this is because the editor's local soft wrap property is being serialized.

data.title: Building on window download-atom-shel
data.body:
## System configuration

OS : Window 8.1
Node version: node-v0.10.28-x86
Python: python-2.7.6
GitHub: 1.3.3.1
Run with GitHub (threw power shell).
## Note

The only thing that I did not do (according to https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/docs/build-instructions/windows.md) was: 

```
$env:Path = $env:Path + ";C:\path\to\atom\repo\node_modules"
```

Because I haven't got any node modules repo.

data.title: Moving tabs between windows don't work
data.body: When having several windows and moving tabs between them, a new tab is created in the receiver window but it's filled with an empty file (the same as "create a new file"), while the tab keeps on the old window.

data.title: Opening files containing only numbers from the Terminal
data.body:
Hello,

if atom tries to open a file from the prompt containing only numbers leads to a crash of the program with the following message:

``` bash
$ touch 123
$ atom 123

TypeError: Arguments to path.resolve must be strings
    at Object.exports.resolve (path.js:327:15)
    at /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/browser/main.js:63:21
    at Array.map (native)
    at Application.<anonymous> (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/browser/main.js:61:43)
    at Application.EventEmitter.emit (events.js:98:17)
    at Application.<anonymous> (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/atom/browser/api/lib/app.js:47:16)
    at Application.g (events.js:190:16)
    at Application.EventEmitter.emit (events.js:101:17)
```

The method causing the problem `path.resolve` is also mentioned in some other issues. This function does only work for strings, but only-numbers-filenames should also be valid.

![atom](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1507474/2936756/f5e105a0-d86f-11e3-9eb4-c202f32e0a61.png)

data.title: Particular directory name causes crash
data.body:
for some reason the particular directory name 'unconf' causes atom to throw up with a pathwatcher error:

```
Error: /Users/mark/github/unconf is a directory
  at new File (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/pathwatcher/lib/file.js:30:15)
  at TextBuffer.module.exports.TextBuffer.setPath (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/text-buffer/lib/text-buffer.js:614:21)
  at new TextBuffer (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/text-buffer/lib/text-buffer.js:82:14)
  at Function.module.exports.Serializable.deserialize (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/serializable/lib/serializable.js:72:22)
  at DeserializerManager.module.exports.DeserializerManager.deserialize (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/deserializer-manager.js:42:29)
  at /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/project.js:84:35
  at Array.map (native)
  at Project.module.exports.Project.deserializeParams (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/project.js:83:39)
  at Function.module.exports.Serializable.deserialize (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/serializable/lib/serializable.js:58:25)
  at DeserializerManager.module.exports.DeserializerManager.deserialize (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/deserializer-manager.js:42:29)
  at Atom.module.exports.Atom.deserializeProject (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/atom.js:300:94)
  at Atom.module.exports.Atom.deserializeEditorWindow (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/atom.js:323:12)
  at Atom.module.exports.Atom.startEditorWindow (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/atom.js:348:12)
  at Object.<anonymous> (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/window-bootstrap.js:14:8)
  at Object.<anonymous> (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/window-bootstrap.js:20:4)
  at Module._compile (module.js:455:26)
  at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:473:10)
  at Module.load (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/coffee-script/lib/coffee-script/register.js:45:36)
  at Function.Module._load (module.js:311:12)
  at Module.require (module.js:363:17)
  at require (module.js:379:17)
  at window.onload (file:///Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/static/index.js:20:5)
```

I deleted and recreated the directory multiple times, ensured permissions were right etc. No dice. If I opened atom inside the directory (via the terminal) using the 'atom' command it barfed. I also tried the directory with and without a git repo in it and it made no difference. It's always that EXACT error too, not different for various files inside the directory, regardless of if I open the directory itself or a file inside it.

Any other directory name is fine, anywhere else I create 'unconf' so far seems to be fine too. Very odd :\

data.title: Detached, centered overlays
data.body:
First steps for issue/feature #964. This provides basic alignment and styling for creating centered overlays.

To create a centered overlay, use the `centered` class instead of the `from-top` class, and call `centerOverlay()` after attaching to the workspace:

``` coffeescript
initialize: ->
  ...  
  @addClass('command-palette overlay centered')
  atom.workspaceView.command 'command-palette:toggle', => @toggle()

...

attach: ->
  ...
  atom.workspaceView.append(this)
  @centerOverlay()
  @focusFilterEditor()
```

data.title: Extract the devPackagePath from PackageManager.
data.body: Give the development-mode package path its own variable and accessor from `PackageManager`. My ulterior motive here is to make a follow-on PR against package-generator, to put generated packages into `.atom/dev/packages` instead of `.atom/packages` by default.

data.title: Bug: Pasting special characters.
data.body:
I experience errors when trying to paste special characters into atom:

![specialcharacters](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5219415/2936017/e7ad7e2c-d83e-11e3-94e3-b5a45dd978e2.png)

As you can see:
- Typing them works.
- Pasting them from other applications does not work.
- Copy & Paste from Atom into Atom itself does not work either.

The characters get saved to the file like that aswell:

```
If I type them: äüöß
If I paste them: ����
```

Atom c79ef0473d604da65a04dee00d140e47c2c5cea2 on Windows 8.1 (x64).

data.title: Use $(...) for command substitution, not backticks
data.body:
Currently both `...` and `$(...)` are used for command substitution. It's better to chose just one and stick to it, to avoid confusion.

Some arguments favoring `$(...)`:
- **Easier to read.** The backtick is easily confused with apostrophes and quotes.
- **Easier to nest.** Nesting backticks commands is an escaping nightmare. Using parenthesis is natural: `$(foo $(bar))`

data.title: Horizontal scrolling is awful.
data.body:
It works awful with 15-inch Retina MacBook Pro's trackpad.
OS X 10.9.2

data.title: [Linux] Closing tab with middle mouse button pastes text in the next open tab
data.body:
The title says it all. The middle mouse button should paste from clipboard on a text area. That happens. But when middle-clicking on tabs, it closes the tab and then pastes from clipboard in the next focused text area. It should not happen.

Here is a video showing the bug: https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/96940816/bug.ogv

data.title: Atom.exe on launch reports %1 is not a valid Win32 Application
data.body:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/84778/2934825/4e5bb43e-d7dd-11e3-8059-2e7d063ad12a.png)

This is after a `script\build` which reported `Done, without errors.` I tried redoing the `grunt install` task and this still happens.

Any ideas?

data.title: Where to post package suggestions?
data.body:
Where can we post suggestions about new packages? 
For example, I would suggest the creating of a package to support Fortran 77, 90 and others. Creation of a package for such an essential language should be undertaken by the atom authors, or at least hosted by them. How do we work that out? Among all the packages that provide similar functionality, the "official" one (by the authors) should be the most preferable one. How does that fit in the apm ecology?

data.title: Advanced context menu
Update docs and fix typos
data.body: Cleaned up typos in Linux build instructions. Added troubleshooting section that can be expanded upon as Fedora, CentOS, Mint, and other distro fixes come rolling in.

data.title: Weird cursor behaviour
data.body:
While using Atom (latest release) I noticed some weird positioning issues. I try using different font families, font sizes etc. and nothing make this issue go away. I even try to build from master but issue remains. It's possible that some plugin is causing this problem.

Here is a screenshots and a video showing that actual position is not the place where character is inserted.

![image 2014-05-09 at 11 36 12 pop](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/590455/2933789/cd6c497e-d7c3-11e3-9906-bfd6c19d54f6.png)

http://cl.ly/VS8z

Closing a file and open it back again clears this issue.

data.title: script/mkdeb doesn't produce pacakge
data.body:
Running script/mkdeb does not produce a .deb file on my machine. Running Ubuntu 12.04.

```
danalbert@danalbert0:~/src/atom$ script/grunt mkdeb
Running "mkdeb" task
Done, without errors.
danalbert@danalbert0:~/src/atom$ find /tmp/atom-build/ -name '*.deb'
danalbert@danalbert0:~/src/atom$
```

What other debug info do you need?
